docs.lead_paragraph: A Chinese herbal compound, gastrodine, used for centuries to treat dizziness and headaches, may help alleviate mild dementia in stroke victims, data from a preliminary study suggest. The research was conducted at Beijing University and the Academy of Traditional Chinese Medicine, where a number of medicines derived from herbs are being tested. The results were presented last week at an American Heart Association conference in Honolulu.
docs.abstract: Beijing University and Academy of Traditional Chinese Medicine present findings at American Heart Association conference that shows herbal compound gastrodine may relieve mild dementia in stroke victims; neurology Professor Dr Edgar J Kenton III of Philadelphia's Thomas Jefferson University questions research, citing that widespread use of herbal medicines within Chinese cultures may have skewed results; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A Chinese herbal compound, gastrodine, used for centuries to treat dizziness and headaches, may help alleviate mild dementia in stroke victims, data from a preliminary study suggest.    The research was conducted at Beijing University and the Academy...

docs.lead_paragraph: Can sunshine, now shunned by so many who fear skin cancer and wrinkles, save many more lives than it harms? Most definitely, says a leading expert in the field, Dr. Michael F. Holick, a professor of medicine, dermatology, physiology and biophysics at the Boston University School of Medicine. Dr. Holick, who discovered the active form of vitamin D, has pulled together an impressive body of evidence in support of his advice that no one should be, as he puts it, a ''sunphobe'' or, for that matter, a sun worshiper.

headline.main: A Second Opinion on Sunshine: It Can Be Good Medicine After All

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column shares importance of vitamin D gained from sun exposure and its effect on general health and as deterrent for disease; Dr Michael F Holick, Boston University professor of medicine, dermatology, physiology and biophysics, concludes that sunshine in appropriate doses is advantageous for all and essential for some; amount of natural melanin, distance from equator and individual's ability to turn vitamin D into vitamin D hormone all influence how much sun is needed; it is estimated that between 90 to 95 percent of personal vitamin D comes from exposure to sunlight; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Can sunshine, now shunned by so many who fear skin cancer and wrinkles, save many more lives than it harms? Most definitely, says a leading expert in the field, Dr. Michael F. Holick, a professor of medicine, dermatology, physiology and biophysics at...

docs.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, I made a decision that up until that time was unthinkable: give up driving a car the traditional way. Multiple sclerosis has numbed my feet to the point where I can no longer tell without looking whether they are on the pedals, and my hip flexors are so weakened that naturally lifting my leg from gas to brake and back again is impossible. For 25 years, driving had always been an enormous pleasure and privilege, and it was now fast becoming riddled with uncertainty, and potentially unsafe.

headline.main: Behind the Wheel With Freedom at the Fingertips

docs.abstract: For many people handicapped because of accidents or disease, driving cannot be taken for granted; projects, such as Adaptive Driving Program, which is supported by nonprofit Association for Driver Rehabilitation Specialists, train disabled individuals on how to drive using abilities not impared, certifies their skills and refers them to companies that will retrofit their cars; work with trainer John Holcomb is described; association website is www.aded.net; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Not long ago, I made a decision that up until that time was unthinkable: give up driving a car the traditional way. Multiple sclerosis has numbed my feet to the point where I can no longer tell without looking whether they are on the pedals, and my...

docs.lead_paragraph: Joel Loveland and G. Z. Brown are self-described evangelists of natural light. As directors of the Better Bricks Daylighting Labs, nonprofit centers devoted to helping architects maximize natural light in their buildings, Mr. Loveland and Mr. Brown consistently preach the benefits of the sun's illumination.

headline.main: Beyond the Bulbs: In Praise of Natural Light

docs.abstract: Architects Joel Loveland and G Z Brown, Better Bricks Daylight Labs directors, support industry use of natural light in building design by supplying architects with tools to enhance design and avoid problems such as unwanted heat and glare; concept is supported by several research studies, including two by Heschong Mahone Group that identify higher tests scores for students attending class in natural light settings; human response is believed to be related to biological, hormonal reaction to light's wavelength, which effects alertness; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Joel Loveland and G. Z. Brown are self-described evangelists of natural light.    As directors of the Better Bricks Daylighting Labs, nonprofit centers devoted to helping architects maximize natural light in their buildings, Mr. Loveland and Mr....

docs.lead_paragraph: The patient walked slowly into my office, took off his hat and collapsed into a vinyl chair. He leaned forward, a bearded, middle-aged man whose bowler hat and neckerchief lent him a vaudevillian air. ''The shortness of breath is getting worse,'' he said, pausing for air. ''The medications you prescribed aren't helping.''
docs.abstract: Cases column discusses why doctors sometimes display dismissive attitude toward alternative therapies; outlines case of patient who used several therapies, including magnets, for ailments as severe as heart failure; suggests doctors be more receptive to patient philosophies on healing and ask more questions in order to discover best treatment (M)
docs.snippet: The patient walked slowly into my office, took off his hat and collapsed into a vinyl chair.    He leaned forward, a bearded, middle-aged man whose bowler hat and neckerchief lent him a vaudevillian air. ''The shortness of breath is getting worse,''...

docs.lead_paragraph: Is it more dangerous to give birth on a weekend, when hospitals are less than fully staffed? The answer from a study released last week was no: while infant mortality rates do appear to be slightly higher on weekends, it is not because of any drop in the quality of care. The link between weekends and higher infant mortality was first noted in the 1970's, said the new study, which was published in The Journal of the American Medical Association. But Dr. Jeffrey B. Gould of the University of California at Berkeley, the study's lead author, said the earlier analyses had not been able to pin down what changed with the day of the week: the babies or the care.
docs.abstract: Dr Jeffrey B Gould, University of California at Berkley researcher, leads study published in Journal of American Medical Association that finds no correlation between medical care and slightly higher mortality rate for babies born on weekends; instead, research shows higher rate is attributable to more planned caesarean births on weekdays and more low birth weight babies born on weekends; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Is it more dangerous to give birth on a weekend, when hospitals are less than fully staffed? The answer from a study released last week was no: while infant mortality rates do appear to be slightly higher on weekends, it is not because of any drop in...

docs.lead_paragraph: It's hard to imagine a doctor more solidly mainstream than Frederick Small, a gynecologist from suburban Tenafly, N.J., with an old-school practitioner's reassuring manner, a grandfather's head of clipped white hair and not much experience with alternative medicine. Yet there he was last week at the New York Botanical Garden, with his laminated name tag and neatly pressed summer shirt, participating in a conference called ''Botanical Medicine in Modern Clinical Practice,'' immersed in the world of roots and decoctions and admiring live specimens like a kava tree.

headline.main: At Bronx Botanical Garden, Mainstream Doctors Meet Kava and Cohosh

docs.abstract: Botanical Medicine in Modern Clinical Practice, New York Botanical Garden conference in its eighth year, attracts estimated 150 participants desiring to learn more about alternative therapies; consumer interest in herbal remedies has motivated some attendees, but gynecologist Dr Frederick Small contends failings of hormone replacement therapy have encouraged him to find new ways to help his patients; Dr Michael J Balick, botanical garden botanist and curator sees interest in herbal medicine growing and studies becoming more detailed to help physicians and individuals make informed choices; photo (M)
docs.snippet: It's hard to imagine a doctor more solidly mainstream than Frederick Small, a gynecologist from suburban Tenafly, N.J., with an old-school practitioner's reassuring manner, a grandfather's head of clipped white hair and not much experience with...

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: BOTANICAL MEDICINE IN MODERN CLINICAL PRACTICE

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors have been working for years to persuade more older Americans to get the flu vaccine. Now a new study suggests that policymakers consider broadening the guidelines on who should get the vaccine against another common killer, invasive pneumococcal disease. Influenza is caused by a virus, which changes so rapidly that a new shot is needed each year. Invasive pneumococcal disease is caused by bacteria, so the effects of the shot are long-lasting.
docs.abstract: Dr Jane E Sisk of Mount Sinai School of Medicine, is lead author of study in Annals of Internal Medicine that suggests pneumonia shot should be given to those age 50 and over as it can greatly reduce occurrence of bacterial disease; contends shot is greatly underused (S)
docs.snippet: Doctors have been working for years to persuade more older Americans to get the flu vaccine. Now a new study suggests that policymakers consider broadening the guidelines on who should get the vaccine against another common killer, invasive...

docs.lead_paragraph: For more than a century, millions of American parents have relied on a library of advice books written by experts on virtually every aspect of their children's health, safety and behavior. Child-rearing problems and solutions, of course, have changed considerably over this period. But one thing has not: in each era, the baby experts have inadvertently inspired a great deal of anxiety among parents already uncertain about their ability to be parents.

headline.main: How to Be the Perfect Parent (And Drown Yourself in Guilt)

docs.abstract: Theories on raising children have been popular book topic for over century, as many adults search for ideal style of parenting and definitive answers on child behavior; parent and journalist Ann Hulbert explores parental insecurities in book Raising America: Experts, Parents, and Century of Advice About Children, as she investigates why parents seek advice; books by child specialists such as Dr Richard Meckel, Dr Benjamin Spock, Dr T Berry Brazelton, Dr William Sears and mother/author Heidi E Murkoff, all seek to help parents, but can give conflicting advice; photos (L)
docs.snippet: For more than a century, millions of American parents have relied on a library of advice books written by experts on virtually every aspect of their children's health, safety and behavior.    Child-rearing problems and solutions, of course, have...

docs.lead_paragraph: People blind from birth are often able to develop superior abilities at using other senses, like hearing. But a study released yesterday finds that they are also able to enlist parts of the brain usually devoted to vision to bolster their memory, even on tasks that involve no sensory input. The study was conducted at Hebrew University in Jerusalem. Its lead author, Amir Amedi, a research fellow, opened the article in Nature Neuroscience by citing a Talmudic tradition that biblical quotations recalled by a blind person should be regarded as accurate.
docs.abstract: Amir Amedi, Hebrew University in Jerusalem research fellow, publishes study performing magnetic resonance brain scans on individuals blind from birth and sighted individuals; study shows reassignment of primary visual cortex to abstract verbal tasks in blind subjects; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: People blind from birth are often able to develop superior abilities at using other senses, like hearing. But a study released yesterday finds that they are also able to enlist parts of the brain usually devoted to vision to bolster their memory,...
